title: Ticket #7289: Implement secure S3 transfers using pre-signed URLs
description:
Downloading from a secure S3 bucket normally means dealing with a tuple of security tokens (two if permanent, three if temporary). Rather than deal with distributing and managing those tokens, Brian Bockelman suggests that we instead transform 's3://' URLs into pre-signed 'https://' URLs in the shadow before we send the list during file-transfer. Doing so for uploads would require an additional round-trip, but keeping the tokens on the submit machine seems like a big win for security.

The function generate_presigned_url() will be implemented in libcondorutils, and based off of the EC2 GAHP's createV4Signature(). While the S3 and EC2 signing protocols are almost identical, the bigger difference deals with moving all of the signature metadata out of the HTTP headers and into the query parameters. For this reason, generate_presigned_url() will share subroutines (which will be moved into libcondorutils) with createV4Signature(), the two functions will not call the same implementation with different flags. 

The shadow will recognize three types of s3:// URLs.
# This form is distinguished by having no '.' before the slash.
s3://<bucket>/<key>
# We check for this pattern so we can automatically extract the region, since AWS cares about it.
s3://<bucket>.s3-<region>.amazonaws.com/<key>
# All other S3 URLs, presumed to be for Ceph or Minio.
s3://<host>/<key>

If the user needs to specify a region, they will be able to do so in the submit file. This region applies to all 's3://' URLs that don't specify a region. Likewise, the same key pair is used for all files, both downloaded and uploaded. (It wouldn't be hard to allow the user to specify a key pair for each direction. Specifying a key pair per file would be hard.)

The shadow will silently rewrite 's3://' URLs for download. For upload, the starter issues a new command to the shadow, asking it to translate a list of URLs; the starter sends the list because support for output file globs means that shadow doesn't actually know them all.
remarks:
2019-Sep-26 20:29:55 by tlmiller:
No, seriously, don't ship it. The branch needs to tested to verify that I didn't accidentally break either the EC2 universe or condor_annex.

It also needs to be tested to make sure the code doesn't require OpenSSL at link time. (It shouldn't need libssl at all, actually, but it can be arranged if necessary.)

It is also incomplete; see the long comment preceding generate_presigned_url(). Short version: Amazon hates you and has already started breaking things, so we need to figure out how to specify endpoints or regions in s3:// URLs (or maybe adopt a different schema from the start).

2019-Sep-26 23:21:27 by bbockelm:
Looking at the Amazon docs, it seems they are doing:

  • http://bucket.s3-aws-region.amazonaws.com (replace "aws-region" with the region name. example: bucket-s3.sa-east-1.amazonaws.com)
  • http://bucket.s3.amazonaws.com (old buckets, defaults to US east).

Looks like old bucket names (and path-style names) default to the us east region.

So, you can unambiguously parse the region from the hostname. Not entirely sure a new scheme is needed?

The real mystery is what the various S3-compatible APIs will do with region information. Looking at the Ceph source code, I'm guessing it actually accepts any arbitrary string...

2019-Sep-27 00:26:11 by tlmiller:
So, you can unambiguously parse the region from the hostname. Not entirely sure a new scheme is needed?

The s3:// scheme defined by the 'aws' CLI is s3://<bucket>/<key>. I suppose we could just ignore that entirely and say that replacing the 'https://' in 'https://<bucket>.s3-<region>.amazonaws.com/<key>' with 's3://' in the file transfer list(s) indicates that you want HTCondor to pre-sign the URL.

2019-Sep-27 08:02:48 by bbockelm:
I think we should do both.

That is,

  • s3://<bucket>/<key> causes the signing code to lookup the region name in the job class ad (defaulting to US east), sign appropriately, and generate the right HTTPS URL with the region name. This shorthand will only apply when there are no . characters in the bucket name.
  • s3://<bucket>.s3-<region>.amazonaws.com/<key> extracts the region name automatically - but only specifically for amazonaws.com.
  • All other URLs of the form s3://... will be assumed to be S3-like (Ceph, minio). Translate the's3://' to a 'https://' prefix and look at the job class ad for the region name (defaulting to us-east-1 if no attribute is set).

2019-Sep-27 10:15:19 by bbockelm:
Ok - with the latest commit, presigning works for both stage-in and stage-out. Tested with a Minio instance -- waiting for S3 credentials to be fixed before testing there.

2019-Sep-27 10:39:23 by tlmiller:
Regarding the comment at condor_utils/file_transfer.cpp:2358 of [57936], does '..' actually have a special meaning for S3? I didn't think it did for the AWS implementation, although I can see that not being true for Ceph or others.

I'm not thrilled with the idea of special handling for magic URLs, but that really may be the least-awful way to manage it. (At least, nothing better comes to mind.)

2019-Sep-27 12:00:18 by bbockelm:
After some discussion:

.. is indeed supposed to be removed from the URL structure as part of the signing process. While there is no specific meaning to those characters at AWS (but perhaps at other places), since they do have meaning in the signature, I would prefer to keep them blacklisted for now.

Better be on the safe side. If it's an impediment, we can remove this safety check and implement RFC3689-style normalization.

2019-Sep-27 14:31:02 by tlmiller:
Testing

  1. Verify that the shadow doesn't have a load-time dependency on libssl. [done]
  2. Verify that the translation code isn't run when spooling or submitting file remotely. [done]
  3. Verify that file globs work for uploading. [done]
  4. Verify that this didn't break the EC2 GAHP or condor_annex. [done]

Known Bugs

  1. AWSRegion does not have a corresponding submit key. [done]
  2. The "EC2" in 'EC2AccessKeyId' and 'EC2SecretAccessKey' is deceptive for this purpose, as is the lack of a 'File' suffix. We should add an alias to fix this. [done]
  3. We should write the documentation after fixing these bugs.
  4. We should encrypt the attribute-value pair we send presigned URLs in (in case the shadow-to-starter channel is not secure). [done]
  5. We do not do match-making on the basis of the starter's ability to ask for presigned output URLs. (I believe the shadow presigns the input URLs without interacting with the starter.) [done]

Follow-Up Work

  1. Should condor_submit -remote spool the credential files, or just fail? Brian is thinking we should use the credmon/credd instead.
  2. We can handle relative "paths" in the S3 URL if it ever turns out anyone needs it.

2019-Oct-01 14:40:09 by tlmiller:
Regarding Testing/3 and Future Work/2: HTCondor (still) doesn't have actual globbing (or regexes) for file upload. However, output_destination is a thing. So for testing uploads with files not known at submission time, we're doing the following: 

transfer_input_files = s3://bucket.s3-region.amazonaws.com/input
output_destination = s3://bucket.s3-region.amazonaws.com/prefix

and it seems to work OK.

In order to recursively transfer unknown directories, I tried the following: 

transfer_input_files = s3://bucket.s3-region.amazonaws.com/input
transfer_output_files = ./
output_destination = s3://bucket.s3-region.amazonaws.com/prefix

This failed, probably because the presigning code doesn't handle URL normalization. The consensus is that this use case isn't worth worrying about for now.

A few minor issues:

  2. The condor_submit alias doesn't seem to work:

Submitting job(s).
